answers.answer: Cinnabon,My suggestion is that you call your doc to clarify what the results mean in your case.  It's terrific, you know, that you're working so diligently to take good care of yourself.Each lab has a "lab normal" range and since you didn't provide that normal range, it's impossible to fully interpret your results.  Since the results showed "out of range," it's good to talk with your doc about it.  In addition to our kidneys' functioning, certain medications can affect the results.So discuss your BUN results specifically with your doc.  It's possible that s/he overlooked something important, and it's possible that your results are of no concern and that's why s/he didn't discuss it.Here are two websites with information about the test:http://www.labtestsonline.org/understanding/analytes/bun/test.htmlhttp://my.webmd.com/hw/kidney_failure/aa36271.asp

Dear cinnabon74,I am a volunteer for JDRF and not a physician, but I am trying to understand your A1c result. I am not qualified to give you medical advice, but I do agree with LRS 's comment.A1c's are normally taken over a few months. Can you tell us what the results are?I have one more question. Are you in touch with a a diet consultant that specializes with type 1 diabetes and carb counting? This would would be the best course.I wish you the best and please look for further comments. Please continue to keep in touch.dm

question: I have a concern...Recently I recieved my blood test back indicating my A1c was a bit bad. I have had real tight control for a month now. My Endo at the time did not mention my (BUN) results and I noticed it reads  out of range at a 35 with a ratio of 39. My Creatinine is 0.9 which is good, but his has me very concerned. Does this improve with better glucose control or is this the result of a diet too high in protein? Can anyone shed some light?
title: (BUN) Blood Test
